posts.post_content:
Lands do have a converted mana cost of zero. You could theoretically search for it, nothing is stopping you. Every card has a converted mana cost, even lands.  
  
202.3a The converted mana cost of an object with no mana cost is 0.

Posted By: LordRandomness (11/29/2011 11:18:39 PM)

posts.post_content:
Almost never worse that [Diabolic Tutor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Diabolic Tutor). The mana cost can be the same and is more flexible, and there's usually not much point in searching up something you can't afford to cast, anyway. And if you have, say, ![4](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=4&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) available but not ![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol), you'll be glad for that flexible cost. You could theoretically even use this in a non-black deck, though it's probably too expensive for that to be practical.  
  
Almost strictly worse than the original [Demonic Tutor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Demonic Tutor), of course (unless you have oodles of non-black mana but no ![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol), of course), but then, so is everything.
posts.html:
Almost never worse that Diabolic Tutor. The mana cost can be the same and is more flexible, and there's usually not much point in searching up something you can't afford to cast, anyway. And if you have, say, available but not , you'll be glad for that flexible cost. You could theoretically even use this in a non-black deck, though it's probably too expensive for that to be practical.

Almost strictly worse than the original Demonic Tutor, of course (unless you have oodles of non-black mana but no , of course), but then, so is everything.
